learning_outcomes.description: Contextualise the role Preclinical Drug Discovery has in the drug life cycle
Identify and explain the role of toxicology in light of preclinical and clinical drug evaluation
Apply the principles of pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics
Justify the role of animal research and the ensuing ethical considerations and regulatory processes
Collaborate and apply skills in research learning
Design and deliver a presentation on scientific research

assessments.due_date:
22/08/2025 - 5/09/2025

Submit the poster by the Friday of the week before your scheduled in-class poster presentation session.
assessments.task_description:
The poster presentation will focus on preclinical drug discovery topics, including in vitro and in vivo research methods for various diseases, on a topic that will be assigned to each student.

  • Prepare a single PowerPoint slide, formatted as an electronic poster.
  • Give an oral presentation using the poster within the poster presentation session during a scheduled workshop.
  • The schedule for poster presentations will be provided on the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site. Submit your electronic file by the Friday prior to your scheduled time.
  • This task is assessed by two rubrics: one for the oral presentation and one for the poster. 50% of the marks are allocated to each assessment.
  • See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for more details, the presentation schedule, and marking rubrics.
  • The presentation will be recorded and retained as per university policy. The recording will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed if required for the purposes of moderation of marking; provision of feedback to the student; and/or re-marking following a successful re-mark application.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit the poster file via the link provided in Learn.UQ (Blackboard). Give the oral presentation in class at your scheduled time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Analyse results from a simulated experiment analysing the active ingredient in a set of tablets. Students will be provided with a data pack in the form of an excel document that is unique to each individual student. Students will use a graphing program, GraphPad Prism, to determine the contents of the active ingredient within the data set and comment on whether it passes the test. The methods of analysis will be covered in an associated tutorial.

See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for more details and the marking criteria.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of the assessment will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your document via the Turnitin link provided in the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
29/08/2025 3:00 pm

Complete the quiz during the 7 days before the due date.
assessments.task_description:
The quiz will assess the content from the Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics module within the course.

  • One attempt is permitted for this quiz.
  • The quiz duration is 60 minutes.
  • The format may be a mixture of question types, for example: multiple choice, multiple answer, matching, ordering, fill in the blank/s, jumbled sentence/s, either/or (e.g. true/false), short answer, and short essay style questions.
  • Questions may be provided randomly from a pool, therefore each student may receive a different but equivalent quiz.
  • The quiz will be marked electronically, correct answers will be awarded the marks indicated beside the question, and incorrect answers will be awarded zero.
  • This is an individual assessment that you are required to undertake without any form of communication with other students.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Complete the quiz online via the Link provided in the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.task_description:
During practical sessions you will conduct Quality Assurance assessments on pharmaceutical tablets according to British Pharmacopeia guidelines. Present the results from the practical as a report. One report is to be submitted by each team, and team members are responsible for ensuring submission is completed.

The assessment is divided into three parts: the project report (30% of semester marks submitted as a group), the laboratory records submitted as an individual and assessed as an individual (5% of the semester), and the peer contribution assessment (5% of the semester).

See Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for details and marking criteria.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of the assessment will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit the report and peer mark via the link in Learn.UQ (Blackboard). Laboratory notebooks will be scanned at the end of the practical for assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Pharmaceutical Analysis and Quality Assurance

These are laboratory based sessions and require you to bring your own personal protective equipment, i.e. laboratory coat and laboratory safety glasses. The practicals will involve quality assurance assays on pharmaceutical tablets. The practicals are split into two 3-hour sessions: morning (9am to 12 pm) and afternoon (2pm to 5 pm). Students will be allocated a time within the timetable and is expected to attend the designated time. Students will work in groups to conduct the analysis and prepare a report (Quality Assurance Research Project Report).

Learning outcomes: L01, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Pharmaceutical Analysis and Quality Assurance These are laboratory based sessions and require you to bring your own personal protective equipment, i.e. laboratory coat and laboratory safety glasses. The practicals will involve quality assurance assays on pharmaceutical tablets. The practicals are split into two 3-hour sessions: morning (9am to 12 pm) and afternoon (2pm to 5 pm). Students will be allocated a time within the timetable and is expected to attend the designated time. Students will work in groups to conduct the analysis and prepare a report (Quality Assurance Research Project Report).

Learning outcomes: L06
